name: Mount Fuji
shortDescription: Sacred mountain and highest peak in Japan, dwelling place of the kami Konohanasakuya-hime
fullDescription: Mount Fuji (ÂØåÂ£´Â±±, Fujisan), standing at 3,776 meters, is Japan's highest mountain and most sacred peak. In mythology, Mount Fuji is closely associated with Konohanasakuya-hime, the blossom princess and wife of Ninigi (grandson of Amaterasu). According to the Taketori Monogatari (Tale of the Bamboo Cutter), the mountain's name derives from 'immortal' (fushi) or 'never dying,' as the elixir of immortality was burned at its summit. Shinto tradition holds that Konohanasakuya-hime dwells within the volcano, her presence manifested in the mountain's fire and beauty. The mountain has been a site of pilgrimage for centuries, with climbers seeking spiritual purification and communion with the kami. Fuji is considered the boundary between earth and heaven, a sacred axis mundi connecting the physical and spiritual realms. The mountain's perfect symmetrical cone represents cosmic harmony and divine perfection.

mythologyContexts.usage: Mount Fuji has been worshipped for over a thousand years as the dwelling of kami. Pilgrims climb the mountain seeking purification, spiritual awakening, and communion with Konohanasakuya-hime. The Fujiko cult (17th-19th centuries) organized pilgrimages believing Fuji was the center of the world. Sengen shrines dedicated to the mountain goddess stand at the summit and base. The mountain represents the perfection of nature and the divine presence within the landscape.
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Mount Fuji represents spiritual ascent, purity, perfection, and the divine within nature. The symmetrical cone symbolizes cosmic harmony and balance. The snow-capped peak represents purity and transcendence. The volcanic fire within connects to Konohanasakuya-hime's fire ordeal. Climbing Fuji is a metaphor for spiritual purification and the soul's journey toward enlightenment. The mountain serves as an axis mundi, connecting earth to heaven.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Mount Fuji is Japan's most iconic symbol, appearing in countless artworks (notably Hokusai's Thirty-Six Views). It is a UNESCO World Heritage site recognized for its cultural significance. The mountain continues to attract hundreds of thousands of pilgrims and tourists annually. Climbing Fuji is considered a spiritual journey, with many ascending at night to witness sunrise from the summit. The mountain embodies Japanese aesthetics of natural beauty and spiritual presence in the landscape.
